expanded_description: Parallel lines are everywhere—from railroad tracks to parking lot lines, from rows in a garden to the edges of a book. In coordinate geometry, parallel lines share the same slope but have different y-intercepts. Understanding how to write equations of parallel lines allows us to model these real-world relationships and solve geometric problems.

core_concept.principle: Two non-vertical lines are parallel if and only if they have the same slope. Vertical lines (with undefined slope) are parallel to each other. To write the equation of a line parallel to a given line through a point $(x_1, y_1)$: (1) Find the slope $m$ of the given line. (2) Use the same slope $m$ with the point in point-slope form: $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$. (3) Simplify to the desired form.
core_concept.explanation: Think of parallel lines as train tracks—they run alongside each other, always the same distance apart, never meeting. The slope is like the direction they're heading. If two lines point in the exact same direction (same slope), they'll never cross, no matter where they start (different y-intercepts).

image.alt: Parallel lines with same slope, different y-intercepts, and formula
image.caption: Figure 5.6.1: Parallel lines share the same slope.

sections.introduction: Before writing equations of parallel lines, let's review the key property: parallel lines have identical slopes.

introduction_image.alt: Multiple parallel lines with same slope
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.2: Parallel lines have the same slope.

key_concept.definition: Two non-vertical lines are parallel if and only if they have exactly the same slope. For example, $y = 2x + 3$ and $y = 2x - 5$ are parallel because both have slope $2$. Vertical lines $x = a$ and $x = b$ are also parallel to each other.
key_concept.context: This property is the foundation for all work with parallel lines. The y-intercepts can be different—in fact, they must be different for distinct parallel lines.

image.alt: Examples of parallel and non-parallel lines
image.caption: Figure 5.6.3: Identifying parallel lines.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Parallel Lines
worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each pair of lines is parallel:
a) $y = 3x + 2$ and $y = 3x - 7$
b) $y = -2x + 5$ and $y = 2x + 5$
c) $y = \frac{1}{2}x + 3$ and $y = \frac{1}{2}x - 4$
d) $x = 4$ and $x = -2$
e) $y = 5$ and $y = -3$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Parallel, b) Not parallel, c) Parallel, d) Parallel, e) Parallel
worked_examples.concept_applied: Parallel lines have equal slopes. Horizontal lines (slope 0) are parallel; vertical lines (undefined slope) are parallel.

sections.introduction: Given a line and a point, we can write the equation of a line parallel to it through that point.

introduction_image.alt: Given line and point, draw parallel line
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.6: Writing a parallel line through a point.

key_concept.definition: To write the equation of a line parallel to a given line through a point $(x_1, y_1)$: (1) Find the slope $m$ of the given line. (2) Use the same slope $m$ with the point in point-slope form: $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$. (3) Simplify to the desired form (slope-intercept or standard).
key_concept.context: This method works for any line given in any form—just extract the slope first. For vertical lines, remember that parallel lines are also vertical.

image.caption: Figure 5.6.7: Process for writing parallel line equations.

worked_examples.title: Writing Parallel Line Equations

image.caption: Figure 5.6.8: Write parallel line through given point.

worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line parallel to the given line through the given point:
a) $y = 2x + 3$, through $(4, 1)$
b) $y = -3x + 5$, through $(-2, 4)$
c) $y = \frac{1}{2}x - 2$, through $(6, 3)$
d) $x = 5$, through $(2, -3)$

step_by_step.explanation: Slope of given line is 2. Use point-slope with (4,1)
Vertical line, so parallel line is also vertical through given point

worked_examples.concept_applied: Use same slope, different point. For vertical lines, parallel lines are also vertical.

process_flow.description: Determine the slope $m$ of the given line. Put in slope-intercept form if needed.
process_flow.mechanism: For $y = mx + b$, slope is $m$. For $Ax + By = C$, slope is $-\frac{A}{B}$.

process_flow.process: Use Same Slope with New Point
process_flow.description: Write point-slope form using the same slope $m$ and the given point $(x_1, y_1)$.
Convert to slope-intercept or standard form as desired.
process_flow.mechanism: Distribute and isolate y, or rearrange to standard form.

image.alt: Summary of writing parallel line equations
image.caption: Figure 5.6.12: Writing parallel lines summary.

sections.introduction: The given line may be in any form. We need to extract its slope before writing the parallel equation.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.13: Finding slope from different equation forms.

key_concept.definition:
To find the slope from different forms:
• Slope-intercept $y = mx + b$: slope $m$ is coefficient of $x$
• Point-slope $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$: slope $m$ is the multiplier
• Standard $Ax + By = C$: slope $m = -\frac{A}{B}$ (when $B \neq 0$)
• Horizontal $y = b$: slope $m = 0$
• Vertical $x = a$: slope undefined
key_concept.context: Once you have the slope, the process is the same regardless of the original form.

image.alt: Table of slope extraction from different forms
image.caption: Figure 5.6.14: Extracting slope from various forms.

worked_examples.title: Parallel Lines from Various Forms

image.caption: Figure 5.6.15: Write parallel lines through given points.

worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line parallel to the given line through the given point:
a) $2x + 3y = 12$, through $(4, 1)$
b) $y - 3 = 2(x + 1)$, through $(2, -3)$
c) $y = 4$, through $(-2, 5)$
d) $x = -3$, through $(1, 4)$

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line, slope = 0. Parallel line is also horizontal through given point
Vertical line, undefined slope. Parallel line is vertical through given point

worked_examples.concept_applied: Extract slope from given line, then use same slope with new point.

image.caption: Figure 5.6.16: Parallel lines from different forms summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes we need to determine whether two lines, possibly given in different forms, are parallel.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.17: Determining if lines are parallel.

key_concept.definition: To determine if two lines are parallel, find the slope of each line (put each in slope-intercept form if needed). If the slopes are equal, the lines are parallel (unless they are the same line). If one slope is undefined (vertical), both must be vertical to be parallel.
key_concept.context: This is useful when working with equations in different forms or when checking your work.

worked_examples.title: Testing for Parallelism

image.caption: Figure 5.6.19: Determine if each pair is parallel.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each pair of lines is parallel:
a) $y = 3x - 2$ and $6x - 2y = 8$
b) $2x + 3y = 12$ and $4x + 6y = 24$
c) $y = \frac{2}{3}x + 5$ and $3y = 2x - 9$
d) $x = 4$ and $y = 2$

step_by_step.calculation: Second: $4x+6y=24$ → $6y=-4x+24$ → $y=-\frac{2}{3}x+4$, same slope AND same intercept → coincident (same line)
Vertical and horizontal are perpendicular, not parallel

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Parallel
b) Coincident (same line)
c) Parallel
d) Not parallel
worked_examples.concept_applied: Find slopes first. Equal slopes = parallel (or coincident). Vertical lines are parallel only to other vertical lines.

sections.introduction: Parallel lines appear throughout the real world—in architecture, transportation, design, and nature.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world examples: railroad tracks, building columns, ruled paper
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.21: Parallel lines in the real world.

categories.description: Railroad tracks, lanes on highways, runways.

examples.explanation: Must remain exactly parallel to keep train on track; constant distance (gauge).

categories.description: Parallel walls, columns, beams, window frames.

examples.explanation: Often arranged in parallel rows for structural integrity and aesthetics.

categories.description: Ruled paper, striped patterns, parking spaces.

image.caption: Figure 5.6.24: Ruled paper has parallel lines.

examples.explanation: Horizontal lines are parallel, equally spaced for writing.

worked_examples.title: Parallel Streets

image.caption: Figure 5.6.25: Parallel streets in a city grid.

worked_examples.problem: In a city grid, Main Street is modeled by $y = 2x + 1$. First Avenue is parallel to Main Street and passes through $(3, 4)$. Write the equation for First Avenue.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world parallel features can be modeled with parallel line equations.

worked_examples.title: Parallel Fencing

image.caption: Figure 5.6.26: Fence lines on a property.

worked_examples.problem: A property line is given by $3x + 4y = 12$. A fence parallel to this property line will be built through point $(8, 2)$. Write the equation of the fence line.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Parallel lines share slope; use given point to find specific line.

image.alt: Summary of real-world parallel line applications
image.caption: Figure 5.6.27: Real-world parallel lines summary.

sections.section_title: 5.6.6 Parallel Lines and Systems of Equations
sections.introduction: Parallel lines are important in systems of equations—they represent systems with no solution.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.6.28: Parallel lines have no intersection.

key_concept.definition: When two lines are parallel and distinct, they have no points in common. In a system of equations, this means the system has no solution. The equations are said to be inconsistent. Graphically, parallel lines never meet.
key_concept.context: Recognizing parallel lines helps us identify systems with no solution without having to solve them completely.

image.alt: Parallel lines on same axes with no intersection
image.caption: Figure 5.6.29: Parallel lines - no solution.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Systems with No Solution

image.caption: Figure 5.6.30: Which systems have no solution?

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each system has no solution (parallel lines), one solution, or infinitely many solutions:
a) $y = 2x + 3$ and $y = 2x - 5$
b) $y = 3x + 1$ and $y = -3x + 1$
c) $2x + 3y = 12$ and $4x + 6y = 24$
d) $x = 4$ and $x = -2$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) One solution, c) Infinitely many, d) No solution
worked_examples.concept_applied: Parallel lines (same slope, different intercepts) have no solution in a system.

image.alt: Summary of parallel lines in systems
image.caption: Figure 5.6.31: Parallel lines and systems summary.

sections.section_title: 5.6.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when working with parallel lines. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Using negative reciprocal instead of same slope.
characteristics: For slope 2, using slope $-\frac{1}{2}$ for parallel

image.caption: Figure 5.6.32: Error - confusing parallel and perpendicular.

examples.process: Error: Saying line parallel to $y = 2x + 3$ has slope $-\frac{1}{2}$
examples.explanation: Correct: Parallel lines have SAME slope, so slope should be 2

classifications.value: Not recognizing that vertical lines are parallel to each other.
characteristics: Treating vertical lines as having no slope comparison
Not writing vertical line equations correctly

examples.process: Error: Saying $x = 3$ and $x = -2$ are not parallel
examples.explanation: Correct: All vertical lines are parallel

classifications.value: Using the given point incorrectly in point-slope form.

worked_examples.title: Correcting Parallel Line Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student wrote the equation of a line parallel to $y = 3x - 2$ through $(4, 5)$ as $y = -\frac{1}{3}x + \frac{19}{3}$. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Given line has slope 3, parallel should also have slope 3

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct: $y = 3x - 7$. Student used perpendicular slope instead of parallel slope.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Parallel lines have the same slope, not negative reciprocal.

image.alt: Summary table of common parallel line errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 5.6.36: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to write equations of parallel lines and solve problems.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
1) Write equation of line parallel to $y = 4x - 3$ through $(2, 5)$.
2) Write equation of line parallel to $2x + 3y = 12$ through $(6, 1)$.
3) Write equation of line parallel to $y = -\frac{1}{2}x + 4$ through $(-2, 3)$.
4) Are $y = 3x + 2$ and $6x - 2y = 8$ parallel?
5) Write equation of line parallel to $x = 5$ through $(2, -3)$.
6) Real-world: Two bike paths are parallel. One is given by $y = \frac{3}{4}x + 2$. The other passes through $(8, 5)$. Write its equation.

step_by_step.explanation: Vertical line, so parallel is vertical through given point

worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice writing equations of parallel lines in various contexts.

summary: Parallel lines are lines that never intersect. In coordinate geometry, non-vertical lines are parallel if and only if they have the same slope. Vertical lines (with undefined slope) are parallel to each other. To write the equation of a line parallel to a given line through a point $(x_1, y_1)$: (1) Find the slope $m$ of the given line (extracting it from whatever form it's in). (2) Use the same slope $m$ with the point in point-slope form: $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$. (3) Simplify to the desired form (slope-intercept or standard). For vertical lines, the parallel line is also vertical: $x = x_1$. In systems of equations, parallel lines represent inconsistent systems with no solution. Real-world applications include parallel streets, railroad tracks, building columns, and ruled paper. Understanding parallel lines is essential for geometry, design, and solving systems of equations.

review_questions_image.alt: Comprehensive summary: definition, writing equations, handling different forms, real-world applications, systems connection
review_questions_image.caption: Figure 5.6.39: Parallel lines equations summary.
